reasoning: The critique targets counterargument (6) in the post: that economic estimates of ρ imply an implausibly low ‘max speed’, so ρ must be closer to 0. This point is supportive but not load-bearing for the overall position, which offers multiple other reasons to doubt applying economy-wide CES elasticities to AI R&D; so centrality is moderate-low. The critique substantially weakens (6) by arguing it is intuition-driven, potentially double-counts compute-dependent steps, and hinges on an underspecified notion of ‘software progress’; this makes the ‘implausibly low’ claim far less decisive, though it doesn’t show the max-speed intuition is wrong. Most claims are reasonable and consistent with the position’s acknowledged uncertainty; minor parts (e.g., the degree of double-counting) are plausible but not clearly established. It is focused, clear, and contains little extraneous material.
title: "Implausibly low max speed" claim lacks empirical grounding
